awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: South Pole Ice Core Chronology and Climate Records using Chemical and Microparticle Measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative project explores the signatures and causes of natural climate change in the region surrounding Antarctica over the last 40,000 years as the Earth transitioned from an ice age into the modern warm period. The researchers will investigate how the wind belts that surround Antarctica changed in their strength and position through time, and document explosive volcanic eruptions and CO2 cycling in the Southern Ocean as potential climate forcing mechanisms over this interval. Understanding how and why the climate varied naturally in the past is critical for improving understanding of modern climate change and projections of future climate under higher levels of atmospheric CO2. 

The investigators plan to conduct a suite of chemical measurements along the 1500m length of the South Pole Ice Core, including major ion and trace element concentrations, and microparticle (dust) concentrations and size distributions. These measurements will (1) extend the South Pole record of explosive volcanic eruptions to 40,000 years using sulfate and particle data; (2) establish the relative timing of climate changes in dust source regions of Patagonia, New Zealand, and Australia using dust flux data; (3) investigate changes in the strength and position of the westerly wind belt using dust size distribution data; and (4) quantify the flux of bioavailable trace metals deposited as dust to the Southern Ocean over time.  These chemistry records will also be critical for creating the timescale that will be used by all researchers studying records from the South Pole core. The project will support four graduate students and several undergraduate students across three different institutions, and become a focus of the investigators' efforts to disseminate outcomes of climate change science to the broader community.

por.por_cntn:
As concern about the timing, magnitude, and rate of future climate change increases, developing a comprehensive understanding of the relevant mechanisms governing climate variability has become crucial. Hypotheses that relate changes in climate forcings and associated responses are critical, particularly across the most recent deglaciation when radiative forcing and internal feedback mechanisms brought the world out of the last ice age. Antarctic ice cores have produced sentinel climate records that underpin much of our current knowledge of global climate variations on glacial-interglacial and millennium time scales, but significant questions remain about the relative magnitude of radiative forcing sources (e.g. volcanic, dust) and the atmospheric circulation response in the Southern Hemisphere. Our project sought to develop cutting-edge chemical and microparticle analyses from a new 54,000 year-long ice core from the South Pole to better understand dust and volcanic emissions relevant to past climate forcing through direct radiative effects, and fertilization of iron-limited waters and resulting CO2 flux, as well as the past response of dominant atmospheric circulation features such as the Southern Hemisphere Westerly Winds (SHWW). 

     The intellectual merit of our work is based on the development, dissemination, and collaborative use of continuous, high-resolution microparticle and chemistry records from the SPICEcore that span the past 54,000 years. These data were used to develop the robust chronology for the SPICEcore, which has allowed subsequent SPICEcore data products to be directly compared to other high-resolution Antarctic and farther-afield paleoclimate data. We developed new techniques for ice core dust shape measurements, and used those shape data to calibrate SPICEcore microparticle records that are related to dust volume. Using these datasets in conjunction with climate models, we investigated sea ice variability in the Southern Hemisphere during the Holocene, and found that wintertime sea ice contracted between 5 and 6,000 years ago which may be coupled with Northern Hemisphere cooling and associated ocean circulation changes. We found that the Southern Hemisphere Westerly Winds shifted southward and intensified during the Holocene, concurrent with southern hemisphere warming, which provides context for changes in the SHWW observed over the past several decades that have implications for CO2 exchange between the atmosphere and Southern Ocean today and into the future. We found that iron derived from atmospheric aerosols, which is an important nutrient source for Southern Ocean ecosystems, has not remained constant over the past 54,000 years. Both the total amount of iron and the amount that might be available to ocean organisms has changed with time. Our results suggest that the proportion of biologically relevant Fe may be controlled by atmospheric water conditions and the activation of local dust source regions in Antarctica. Overall, these findings have implications for the interpretation of glacial/interglacial changes in atmospheric carbon dioxide and the ocean-atmosphere carbon cycle in general.

     The broader impacts of our work include support and development for an early career scientist, and the training and development of graduate and undergraduate students in field skills, laboratory procedures, analytical chemistry techniques, professional science skills, and science communication. Ideas and results of this project were also used in the development of an online teaching module in systems thinking, which is now used in hundreds of classes and by thousands of students nationwide. We incorporated the systems thinking module and project data into a popular course at UMaine (ERS201: Global Environmental Change) that is required in the Earth and Climate Sciences and Ecology and Environmental Sciences undergraduate curricula.  ERS201 also served as a training and development opportunity for a PhD student who subsequently landed a position at the teaching-focused undergraduate institution, and for a research scientist who taught the class and gained significant pedagogical experience.
